Award.AwardTitle: Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Recognizing that the neurosciences are a vibrant and dynamic area of research, with implications for biology, STEM education, behavioral and cognitive science, engineering, computer science, medicine, and understanding of the human condition, the Institute of Medicine (IOM) established in 2006 a Forum on the Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders. With funding from the National Science Foundation, the Forum brings together leaders from private sector, sponsors of basic, biomedical and clinical research, federal agencies, foundations, the academic community, and consumers. Through its regular meetings and public workshops, the Forum provides a venue where its members, other leaders from the neurosciences and related disciplines, and members of the public can have important discussions about issues of mutual interest. The Forum has undertaken a broad set of initiatives, including meetings on data sharing, the BRAIN initiative, and neuroscience workforce development. The Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders focuses on building partnerships and enabling interdisciplinary large-scale research between the basic and applied sciences, which will be necessary to understand the brain and nervous system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine’s Forum on Neuroscience and Nervous System Disorders (the "Neuroscience Forum") was established in 2006 to bring together leaders from government, academia, industry, and the non-profit sector to examine significant—and sometimes contentious—issues concerning scientific opportunities, priority setting, and policies related to research on neuroscience and brain disorders; the development, regulation, and use of interventions for the nervous system; and related ethical, legal, and social implications.

The Neuroscience Forum provides a communal, neutral venue to foster dialogue across sectors and institutions. Representatives from government, academia, industry, non-profit associations, philanthropic foundations, and other interested parties serve as members of the Neuroscience Forum. Members meet two or three times per year to exchange information, ideas, and differing perspectives regarding emerging scientific and policy issues related to research in the neurosciences. Specific topics addressed at Neuroscience Forum membership meetings during this award period have included, for example, neuroscience training/workforce needs for the 21st Century; data sharing; decision-making among venture capital companies and views about the readiness of areas within neuroscience for commercialization; federal programs and agendas (e.g., the Brain Research through Advancing Innovative Neurotechnologies [BRAIN] Initiative); current and future challenges to data security, the economy, defense, and health; transgenic and chimeric non-human primates models in neuroscience; and antisense oligonucleotides and gene therapy for nervous system disorders.

In addition to membership meetings, every year the Neuroscience Forum hosts two or three public workshops on topics selected by the membership. Following each workshop, a proceedings is published by the National Academies Press and made available as a free downloadable PDF at http://www.nap.edu. The Neuroscience Forum regularly tackles topics that integrate fundamental neuroscience research with preclinical and clinical research to help advance development of therapies for nervous system disorders, which are common, major causes of premature mortality, and, in aggregate, the largest cause of disability worldwide. During the 2015-2018 award period, the Neuroscience Forum hosted workshops and published workshop proceedings on the following topics:

  • Harnessing Mobile Devices for Nervous System Disorders (proceedings forthcoming)
  • Neuroforensics: Exploring the Legal Implications of Emerging Neurotechnologies (2018)
  • Advancing Therapeutic Development for Pain and Opioid Use Disorders through Public-Private Partnerships (2018)
  • Enabling Novel Treatments for Nervous System Disorders by Improving Methods for Traversing the Blood-Brain Barrier (2018)
  • Biomarkers of Neuroinflammation (2017)
  • International Perspectives on Integrating Ethical, Legal, and Social Considerations into the Development of Non-Invasive Neuromodulation Devices (2017)
  • Therapeutic Development in the Absence of Predictive Animal Models of Nervous System Disorders (2017)
  • Developing Multimodal Therapies for Brain Disorders (2017)
  • Neuroscience Trials of the Future (2016)
  • Assessing the Impact of Applications of Digital Health Records on Alzheimer’s Disease (2015)
  • Providing Sustainable Mental and Neurological Health Care in Ghana and Kenya (2015)

One of the Forum's recent areas of focus has been developing a neuroscience workforce that can meet the challenges of the 21st century. The activities in this area have included a workshop, publication of workshop proceedings, a Forum working group, an individually-authored article in Neuron, a highly attended online Reddit Ask Me Anything discussion, and participation by two working group members in a panel on training at the 2016 annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience. In addition, these materials have been used by the Society for Neuroscience’s Neuroscience Training Committee, which now will work to translate them into action at the graduate program level.

Overall, the Neuroscience Forum’s activities aim to inspire new ideas and shape the field, foster relationships and collaboration, develop an improved understanding of each other’s perspectives and priorities, and influence policies and programs. Discussions or workshops may lead to proposals for specific studies by units of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine resulting in institutional reports. Such studies, if undertaken, will be conducted independently from the Neuroscience Forum and in accordance with all institutional policies and procedures governing such study activities.
